document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic review of the Dichotomius (Luederwaldtinia) agenor species group (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Scarabaeinae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Dichotomius centralis
–
Halffter & Matthews 1966: 1
. —
Kohlmann & Solís 1997: 345
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Dichotomius centralis
is separated from the other species in the group by the following combination of characters: pronotum covered by dense subrugose punctures. Elytral striae strongly marked, wide and crenulate, easily observable by unaided eye, punctures undefined and crenulate, separated by the width of a puncture.

GUATEMALA • 1 ♂ , 2 ♀♀ ; Suchitepequez , Cuyatenango , Chacalte Sia ; V
Jun. 1993
; E. Espana ; CEMT
.
LEGS. Metacoxa posterior edge bearing single row of organized ocellate setigerous punctures, separated by width of a puncture.
PARAMERES AND LAMELLA COPULATRIX. As in Fig. 6C , E–F.
As males except for the following characters:
HEAD. Surface completely rugose. Fronto-clypeal carina quadridentate, median tubercles higher than lateral.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 6.
Dichotomius centralis ( Harold, 1869 )
. A–B . Dorsal habitus. A . ♂. B . ♀. C . Lateral view of the aedeagus. D . Anterior view, head surface rugose, pronotal anterior surface showing subrugose punctation. E . Ventral view of the aedeagus. F–G . Lamella copulatrix. H . Elytral striae with crenulate punctures.

subSubSection.paragraph: PRONOTUM. Weak medial knob, inconspicuous, observable in lateral view. Anterior and lateral surface covered by subrugose punctures fading towards medial disc. Hypomeron setae longer and denser than in males.
ELYTRA. Striae wider. Striae punctation undefined, crenulate and separated by half, or less width of a puncture.

This species occurs in Belize , Costa Rica and Guatemala . The original description specified that the type series was collected in Granada , Nicaragua . Other published works report it for El Salvador ( Kohlmann & Solís 1997 ; López-Guerrero 2005 ). López-Guerrero (2005) argues that it is marginally likely to find this species in the south of Mexico , precisely in the state of Chiapas due to the proximity to Guatemala .
